issuetype.description: A task that needs to be done.
issuetype.name: Task

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

comments.body:
Still need to:
  - -Fix release date (index file)-
  - -Fix Euca2ools release number and date (index file)-
  - -Fix OSG concepts section (currently empty file)-
  - Finalize service separation content
  - -Finalize release notes-
  - -add updated schema docs-
  - -merge web-docs 4.0.0 with master-
  - -Fix bad link: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/ACLUsingRESTAPI.html (manage_resources_walrus.html)-
  - -Looks like "dashboard" still shows up (remove this remnant of admin console)-
  - -enter licensing changes into install package narrative-

[~smarvin]

Willing to review with you whenever you can/want to. Here is my first pass up through installation:


   * Installation overview


     -Quick deploy mentions 1 or two machines but we don’t have the 2 machine thing done yet-
      -For quick deploy we will need to change the URL to be the “nicer looking one”-

         -https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/MAR-1009-
         -https://www.eucalyptus.com/install-  


   * In component overview

      ** No discussion of UFS here (i think on purpose)
      ** Walrus is no longer User Facing though so you actually interact with the UFS with S3 tools not the Walrus
      ** If this should be broken down into S3 Providers: Walrus vs Riak CS
      ** In cluster controller, for edge the CC no longer handles VM networking, it happens on the NC

   * System Requirements

      ** Compute Requirements

         *** We no longer need KVM to be installed before hand, the eucalyptus-nc package brings it in automatically

      ** Network requirements

         *** 4th bullet should read, for VM traffic isolation the network ports connecting the Ethernet interfaces may need to allow VLAN trunking.
         *** 5th bullet, For MANAGED modes, Eucalyptus requires that you make available two sets of IP addresses.
         *** For edge you need to have at least 1 existing network for Euca to use
         *** For 6th bullet add a link to the multicast connectivity test

            **** 
https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/preparing_connectivity.html





   * Architecture Overview

      ** Diagram needs to be updated for 4.0 features

         *** All UFS including S3 and EC2 on the CLC
         *** Imaging VM on an NC

      ** The last paragraph alludes to system and static mode, I assume we are punting on gutting that stuff ATM

   * Plan component placement

      ** Cloud components

         *** [MUST HAVE] Last paragraph talks about Walrus as though it were user facing, should talk about OSG

      ** Node components

         *** [MUST HAVE] In EDGE the NCs must have network connectivity to the internet if you’d like your VMs to be able to reach the internet. This is already mentioned in the EDGE section so likely disregard.


   * Plan Networking Modes

      **  Both EDGE and MANAGED say they offer the most features, we should just say they offer full network feature functionality.
      ** [MUST HAVE]  EDGE does not work with VMware
      ** Remove SYSTEM and STATIC mode here?

   * Configure Dependencies

      ** Enable IP Forwarding

         *** [MUST HAVE] This needs to be done on NCs running EDGE mode as well
         *** [MUST HAVE] Additionally you should set this param as well:

            **** net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables = 1



   * Installing from Eucalyptus Release Packages

      ** [MUST HAVE] For Eucalyptus Subsrcibers they will get two packages and can install then at the same time:

         *** [MUST HAVE] yum install eucalyptus-enterprise-release-4.0*.noarch.rpm eucalyptus-license-*.rpm


   * Configure Eucalyptus

      ** Configuring for EDGE mode

         *** [MUST HAVE] We need a break down of what each thing means, the config is quite opaque and hard to figure out

            **** InstanceDnsDomain - this is the internal DNS domain used for instance private DNS names
            **** InstanceDnsServers - a list of servers that instances will receive in order to resolve DNS names
            **** Subnets - These are subnets which you do not which the Eucalyptus edge implementation to put on the public facing network. These will be forward directly without having their source addresses remapped to the Public facing address
            **** Clusters: A list of of cluster objects that define each of the Availability Zones in your cloud

               ***** Name: The name of the cluster as it was registered
               ***** MacPrefix: the first 2 octets of any VMs mac address launched in this cluster
               ***** Subnet: The definition of the subnet that this cluster will use for private addressing

                  ****** Name: An arbitrary name for the subnet
                  ****** Subnet: The Subnet that will be used for private addressing
                  ****** Netmask: The net mask for the subnet defined above
                  ****** Gateway: The gateway that will route packets for the private subnet

               ***** PrivateIps: the private IPs that will be handed out to instances as they launch

And where to put this new param info:

Configure Dependencies
Enable IP Forwarding
This needs to be done on NCs running EDGE mode as well
Additionally you should set this param as well:
net.bridge.bridge-nf-call-iptables = 1
Thanks, [~tony]. Got these changes in.

[~smarvin],

Here are some additional changes which I think we need to get in:

* Updating _Configure SSL_ in 'Manage Security' section of Administration Guide
** https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#security-guide/configuring_ssl.html - we still talk about CLC and Walrus for configuring SSL.  From my understanding, this won't be needed.  We should have documentation discussing how to set up the following:
*** Setting up SSL for User Facing Services 
*** (Tech Preview Only) Setting up SSL for CloudFormations

[~kedwards], can we have someone from the Services team provide information on the two topics above?

The content in this comment is done.

1. on https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/upgrade_packages.html
script should be: 
for host in 28 29 32 33 35 39 40; do echo 192.168.51.$host; ssh 192.168.51.$host 'yum -y update $( rpm -qa | grep euca )' ; done
2. Link at bottom here: https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/upgrade_start.html
should link to: https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/sync_keys_components.html
Not: https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/upgrade_verify.html
3. Step 4 here: https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/sync_keys_components.html 
should include:  yum install eucalyptus-imaging-worker-image
4. Page is redundant: https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/registering_services_upgrade.html
5. on https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/upgrade_verify.html
step 1. euca_conf --list-walruses should be euca_conf --list-walrusbackends

Update the following page - https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#user-guide/monitoring_concepts.html

Should include information about Cooldown Period - http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AutoScaling/latest/DeveloperGuide/AS_Concepts.html#Cooldown

This is really important for users to understand; especially when dealing with scaling activities.  Maybe its good enough to just add a section labeled 'Cooldown Period', with a small paragraph, then a link to the resource above.  [~tony], would that be good enough?

Update the following page - https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_basic_config.html

*Section*

Optionally, you can create listeners for the load balancer as follows:
{code}
eulb-create-lb-listeners --listener "lb-port=PORT, protocol=PROTOCOL,
                                    instance-port=PORT, instance-protocol=PROTOCOL, 
                                    cert-id=ARN"
                         ELB
{code}

_We should update this to the following:_

Optionally, you can create listeners for the load balancer as follows:

{code}
eulb-create-lb-listeners --listener "lb-port=PORT, protocol=PROTOCOL,
                                    instance-port=PORT, instance-protocol=PROTOCOL"
                         ELB
{code}

If HTTPS/SSL is being used for the Load Balancer's _protocol_, please do the following:

* Reference the section ['Uploading SSL Certificates for Elastic Load Balancing'|https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#user-guide/elb_examples_ssl_certificates.html] to make sure the SSL is uploaded for the ELB.
* Add a listener with the following options:
{code}
eulb-create-lb-listeners --listener "lb-port=PORT, protocol=PROTOCOL,
                                    instance-port=PORT, instance-protocol=PROTOCOL, 
                                    cert-id=ARN"
                         ELB
{code}
I think, EUCA-8650 still goes into 4.0.0 known issues, though we have it in 3.4.2 known issues.

Good catch, Shaon. Thank you.


On Thu, May 29, 2014 at 9:40 AM, Imran Hossain Shaon (JIRA) <

Improvements to 'Pre-Defined Roles' section - https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#admin-guide/access_roles.html

*\[Improvement Suggestion\]*

Eucalyptus offers a number of pre-defined privileged roles. These roles are associated with the eucalyptus account, and have privileges to manage resources across the cloud and non-privileged accounts. Only the eucalyptus account can manage or modify these roles.

To see the pre-defined roles, use _euare-rolelistbypath_ with the credentials of a user that is part of the _eucalyptus_ account.  For example:
{code}
# euare-rolelistbypath 
arn:aws:iam::944786667073:role/eucalyptus/AccountAdministrator
arn:aws:iam::944786667073:role/eucalyptus/InfrastructureAdministrator
arn:aws:iam::944786667073:role/eucalyptus/ResourceAdministrator
{code}

*Account Administrator*

The Account Administrator (AA) can manage Eucalyptus accounts.  To view the policy associated with the Account Administrator role, use _euare-rolelistpolicies_ with the credentials of a user that is part of the _eucalyptus_ account.  For example:
{code}
# euare-rolelistpolicies --role-name AccountAdministrator --verbose
AccountAdministrator
{
  "Statement":[ {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": [
      "iam:*"
    ],
    "NotResource": "arn:aws:iam::eucalyptus:*",
    "Condition": {
      "Bool": { "iam:SystemAccount": "false" }
    }
  } ]
}
IsTruncated: false
{code}

*Resource Administrator*

The Resource Administrator (RA) can manage AWS-defined resources (such as S3 objects, instances, users, etc) across accounts.  To view the policy associated with the Resource Administrator role, use _euare-rolelistpolicies_ with the credentials of a user that is part of the _eucalyptus_ account.  For example:
{code}
# euare-rolelistpolicies --role-name ResourceAdministrator --verbose
ResourceAdministrator
{
  "Statement":[ {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": [
      "autoscaling:*",
      "cloudwatch:*",
      "ec2:DescribeInstanceAttribute",
      "ec2:DescribeInstances",
      "ec2:DescribeInstanceStatus",
      "ec2:DescribeInstanceTypes",
      "ec2:GetConsoleOutput",
      "ec2:GetPasswordData",
      "ec2:ImportInstance",
      "ec2:ModifyInstanceAttribute",
      "ec2:MonitorInstances",
      "ec2:RebootInstances",
      "ec2:ReportInstanceStatus",
      "ec2:ResetInstanceAttribute",
      "ec2:RunInstances",
      "ec2:StartInstances",
      "ec2:StopInstances",
      "ec2:TerminateInstances",
      "ec2:UnmonitorInstances",
      "ec2:*AccountAttributes*",
      "ec2:*Address*",
      "ec2:*AvailabilityZones*",
      "ec2:*Bundle*",
      "ec2:*ConversionTask*",
      "ec2:*CustomerGateway*",
      "ec2:*DhcpOptions*",
      "ec2:*ExportTask*",
      "ec2:*Image*",
      "ec2:*InternetGateway*",
      "ec2:*KeyPair*",
      "ec2:*NetworkAcl*",
      "ec2:*NetworkInterface*",
      "ec2:*PlacementGroup*",
      "ec2:*ProductInstance*",
      "ec2:*Region*",
      "ec2:*ReservedInstance*",
      "ec2:*Route*",
      "ec2:*SecurityGroup*",
      "ec2:*Snapshot*",
      "ec2:*SpotDatafeedSubscription*",
      "ec2:*SpotInstance*",
      "ec2:*SpotPrice*",
      "ec2:*Subnet*",
      "ec2:*Tag*",
      "ec2:*Volume*",
      "ec2:*Vpc*",
      "ec2:*Vpn*",
      "ec2:*VpnGateway*",
      "elasticloadbalancing:*",
      "s3:*"
    ],
    "Resource": "*"
  }, {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": [
      "iam:Get*",
      "iam:List*"
    ],
    "NotResource": "arn:aws:iam::eucalyptus:*"
  } ]
}
IsTruncated: false
{code}

*Infrastructure Administrator*

The Infrastructure Administrator (IA) can perform operations related to cloud setup and management. Typical responsibilities include:

* Installation and configuration (prepare environment, install Eucalyptus, configure Eucalyptus)
* Monitoring and maintenance (infrastructure supporting the cloud, cloud management layer, upgrades, security patches, diagnostics and troubleshooting)
* Backup and restoration

To view the policy associated with the Infrastructure Administrator role, use _euare-rolelistpolicies_ with the credentials of a user that is part of the _eucalyptus_ account.  For example:
{code}
# euare-rolelistpolicies --role-name InfrastructureAdministrator --verbose
InfrastructureAdministrator
{
  "Statement":[ {
    "Effect": "Allow",
    "Action": [
      "euprop:*",
      "euserv:*",
      "euconfig:*",
      "ec2:MigrateInstances"
    ],
    "Resource": "*"
  } ]
}
IsTruncated: false
{code}

Improvement - Configure the Storage Controller (https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/configure_storage_controller.html)

Customers have complained in the past that how this section is presented is confusing.  Right now, the layout in the left-side menu is as follows:

* Configuring the Storage Controller
** Configure Dell Equallogic Multipathing
** Configure EMC VNX Multipathing
** Configure NetApp Multipathing

This confuses users when they want to configure a default Equallogic, VNX or NetApp.  Would it be possible to restructure this layout?  Maybe to something similar to the following:

* Configuring the Storage Controller
** Configuring the SC to use the local filesystem (Overlay)
** Enable Direct Attached Storage (JBOD) SANs
** Enable Dell Equallogic SANs
*** Configure Dell Equallogic Multipathing
** Enable NetApp SANs
*** Enable NetApp 7-mode SANs
*** Enable NetApp Clustered Data ONTAP SAN
*** Configure NetApp Multipathing
** Enable EMC VNX SANs
*** Configure EMC VNX Multipathing

Improvement - Eucalyptus Installation / Configure the Runtime Environment / Configure DNS - https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/setting_up_dns.html

A few things here:

* We don't mention the following DNS properties, and if they can/can't be changed:
** dns.dns_listener_address_match
** dns.instancedata.enabled
** dns.ns.enabled
** dns.services.enabled
** dns.services.hostmapping
** dns.spoof_regions.enabled
** dns.spoof_regions.region_name
** dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions
** dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions
** dns.tcp.timeout_seconds
** objectstorage.s3provider.s3usebackenddns (this is mentioned here - https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#shared/osg_additional_config.html - however it would be helpful if there could be a link from the 'Configure DNS' page to the 'OSG Advanced Configuration' page

* Under the section 'Advanced DNS Options', we have the following:
{quote}
Recursive lookups and split-horizon DNS are available in Eucalyptus.

1. To enable any of the DNS resolvers, set dns.enabled to true.
2. To enable the recursive DNS resolver, set dns.recursive.enabled to true.
3. To enable split-horizon DNS resolution for internal instance public DNS name queries, set dns.split_horizon.enabled to true.
{quote}
This is the default on Eucalyptus DNS enabled/disabled clouds, so therefore this is incorrect.  I think we should update this to explain when these are actually used (i.e. are they honored when Eucalyptus DNS is disabled).

* In Edge networking (https://www-stage.eucalyptus-systems.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#install-guide/nw_edge.html)
To change instance DNS domain, the following needs to be done:
* Change the cloud property 'cloud.vmstate.instance_subdomain'
{code}
$ euca-modify-property -p cloud.vmstate.instance_subdomain=<instance subdomain>
{code}
* Update the 'InstanceDnsDomain' property in the JSON file, and upload to the cloud property 'cloud.network.network_configuration':
{code}
$ euca-modify-property -f cloud.network.network_configuration=</path/to/your/config_file.json>
{code}

Hey [~smarvin],

Looks like in our documentation under [Troubleshooting Guide => Log Files|https://www.eucalyptus.com/docs/eucalyptus/4.0/index.html#troubleshooting-guide/ts_logs.html], we didn't mention the location of the log files for the Image Worker or the Elastic Load Balancer.  Thinking the entry should be something like this:

{panel:title=Image Worker|titleBGColor=#E8E8E8}
Logs on the Image Worker image are stored are stored in /var/log/eucalyptus-imaging-worker.  The relevant log file is as follows:
\\
\\
* worker.log

{panel}

{panel:title=Elastic Load Balancer (ELB)|titleBGColor=#E8E8E8}
Logs on a given Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) are stored in /var/log/load-balancer-servo.  The relevant log file is as follows:
\\
\\
* servo.log

{panel}

Hey [~smarvin],

The following euare commands are missing from the Euca2ools Guide:

* euare-servercertdel
* euare-servercertgetattributes
* euare-servercertlistbypath
* euare-servercertmod
* euare-servercertupload

Hey Harold, let's start opening new tickets for doc issues, from this point
on. I'm going to separate out the issues in this one. Thanks.


On Sat, May 31, 2014 at 8:07 PM, Harold Spencer Jr. (JIRA) <

Hey [~smarvin],

No problem.  Is there a special tag you want me to add to the tickets?

Nope. Let's just use the ticket title for whatever the issue is.

Thanks, Harold!


On Sun, Jun 1, 2014 at 9:01 AM, Harold Spencer Jr. (JIRA) <
Issues that weren't fixed were given their own tickets.
